INDONESIAN RHIO WATERS CLOSED TO SINGAPORE COASTAL
VESSELS
(Effect on Singapore Seamen and Singapore's economy)


    1. Mr Thio Chan Bee asked the Deputy Prime Minister to state whether, and why Indonesian Rhio waters are now closed to Singapore coastal vessels, to what extent this has affected the employment of Singapore seamen and Singapore's economy, and what the Government proposes to do to assist the people adversely affected.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: As far as the Singapore Government is aware, Indonesian waters are not closed to Singapore coastal vessels. We have not received any indication that there is any such ban on non-Indonesian vessels.

    Mr Thio Chan Bee: Mr Speaker, Sir, is the Deputy Prime Minister aware that the new conditions imposed are such that they practically make it difficult for

Column: 1182

Singapore seamen to be employed on Singapore vessels going to Indonesian waters?

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: What is the Member for Tanglin talking about? I have just said that we do not know for a fact that non-Indonesian vessels are being prohibited from entering Rhio waters. I do not understand what conditions the Member for Tanglin is referring to.

    Mr Speaker: It seems to be a different question anyway.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Is the Deputy Prime Minister aware that such a report appeared in the local Press?

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: The trouble with the Members of the Opposition is this; that they follow the footsteps of the Member for Tanglin and believe that every printed word is the gospel truth. I would, however, recommend him to read the less sensational parts of the newspapers.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Mr Speaker, I have not yet got an answer to my question.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: What the local Press publishes is not my business. I have given an answer.

    Mr Speaker: No Ministerial responsibility. Tun Lim.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: It is because of the report in the local Press that there has been disquiet in the minds of the people concerned. Surely, if there has been no such knowledge on the part of the Government that there is such a restriction, then it would be advisable for the Government to set at rest the minds of those people who are misled by the Press?

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: The answer is very simple. Supposing the local Press reports that a space ship from Mars has landed at Bukit Timah Heights in Singapore. I suppose Members of the Opposition will also ask questions in the Assembly.

Column: 1183

people of Singapore, but the banning of ships in Indonesian waters does.- [Interruption].

    Mr Speaker: Order. I think we are entering into a debate. Inche Mohamed Ali.

MOBILE CLINICS IN CITY AND RURAL AREAS


    2. Inche Mohd. Ali Bin Alwi asked the Minister for Health what is the number of mobile clinics operating in the City Area and in the Rural Areas; and whether the treatment given by such clinics is free of charge.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health (Dr Sheng Nam Chin) (for the Minister for Health): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have been asked to reply. It is presumed that the question refers to travelling dispensaries and not travelling clinics. In which case, the answer is that no mobile or travelling dispensaries are operating at present in the City area.

    There are, however, four travelling dispensaries operating in the rural areas, and the treatment given in these travelling dispensaries is free.

    Inche Mohd. Ali Bin Alwi(In Malay): Mr Speaker, is it the intention of the Government to increase the number of travelling dispensaries?

    Dr Sheng Nam Chin: Can the Member please repeat the question?

    Inche Mohd. Ali Bin Alwi(In Malay): Mr Speaker, is it the intention of the Government to increase the figure mentioned?

    Dr Sheng Nam Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, can I please ask the Member whether he is referring to these travelling dispensaries in the City or the rural areas?

    Inche Mohd. Ali Bin Alwi(In Malay): Concerning the four travelling dispensaries operating in the rural areas, I wish to know whether the number mentioned will be increased.

    Dr Sheng Nam Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, it is not envisaged that the number will be increased, but the Government will build more clinics in the rural areas

Column: 1184

to serve the people. It is felt that a travelling dispensary is only a very temporary provision for the medical services compared to a rural clinic.

    Inche Mohd. Ali Bin Alwi(In Malay): Mr Speaker, according to the information supplied, the medical treatment given is free. But to the best of my knowledge, some time ago 50 cents was charged for each treatment. When will such fees be waived?

    Dr Sheng Nam Chin: As I mentioned previously, there were two types of travelling dispensaries. One was the city travelling dispensary and the other was the rural travelling dispensary. The city travelling dispensaries were previously controlled by the City Council, and it was necessary for those who attended the city travelling dispensaries to pay 50 cents for treatment. Since 1959, however, because of better services being provided in the City, it was deemed unnecessary to carry on with the city travelling dispensaries. Hence all the travelling dispensaries were shifted to the rural areas. Therefore, no payment was asked for.

NATIONAL LANGUAGE WEEK OR MONTH


    7. Inche Mohd. Ali Bin Alwi asked the Minister for Culture whether he will hold a National Language Week or Month.

Column: 1187



    Mr S. Rajaratnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, we have a number of schemes to popularise and teach the National Language, and the holding of a Language Week is one of them. The Head of the Dewan Bahasa dan Kebudayaan Kebangsaan is working on a scheme to make people more conscious of the need to learn the National Language. In the middle of this year, we will be introducing Suara Singapura, which will be held to stimulate interest in the understanding of the National Language. However, I cannot indicate at the moment what form the Language Week will take, because we must take into consideration the special conditions in Singapore. Singapore is largely a non-Malay speaking territory and so a campaign of this kind, while stimulating the people to use the national language, should not cause undue inconvenience to administration and business. Furthermore, the campaign must be planned in such a way as to make it easy and practical for non-Malay speaking citizens as well to participate in it effectively. In fact, the effectiveness and usefulness of such a campaign would be lost if it is of so ambitious and complex a nature that the majority of the people cannot participate in it, not because they do not want to but because it demands things beyond their capacity.

    Inche Mohd. Ali Bin Alwi(In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, could the Minister concerned state definitely when a National Language Week or Month will be held this year?

    Mr Rajaratnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have said earlier that I cannot indicate at the moment when and in what form the National Language Week would take, but we are working on it and as soon as the necessary arrangements are made, we will publicise the fact.

    Inche Mohd. Ali Bin Alwi(In Malay): Could the Minister not even give a slight indication as to whether it is possible to hold the National Language Week some time this year?

    Mr Rajaratnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, when this Government makes a promise, it keeps its promise. Therefore, I

GOVERNMENT SCHOOL IN MALAY FARM AREA OF ALSAGOFF
ESTATE


    8. Inche Mohd. Ali Bin Alwi asked the Minister for Education whether he has any plan for building a Government school in the Malay Farm area of Alsagoff Estate.

    The Government is, however, building a 24-classroom primary school at Jalan Kaki Bukit. This new school is expected to be completed in August this year, and it will serve the children in the Malay Farm area as well. We hope to purchase in the very near future another site for the erection of two Government schools which will not only cater for the children in the Malay Farm area but also for those in the Geylang Serai area.

    A site has recently been acquired in Jalan Kembangan for a 24-classroom primary school which is expected to be ready by early 1962. It should be explained that each 24-classroom primary school will be able to accommodate more than 2,000 students in both sessions.

LAND TITLES (AMENDMENT) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

2.54 p.m.

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Mr Speaker, Sir, this Bill and the following Bill which I will be moving for Second Reading concern certain esoteric points in the law of conveyancing.

    As regards the Land Titles Ordinance, I would like to remind the House that it was first passed in 1956 and it was not brought into operation until 1st December, 1960. As from that date, under section 8 of the Ordinance, all land alienated by the Crown will be brought under the provisions of the Ordinance and certificates of title will be issued in lieu of Crown instruments. However, since 1956, there have been a number of surrenders by land developers under section 11 of the Crown Lands Ordinance for the purpose of sub-dividing their land into smaller lots for building purposes. Some 1,200 lots in the case of the Sembawang Hill Estate and another 1,000 odd lots in the case of the Serangoon Garden Estate have already been sub-divided. In both these cases, Crown grants have not yet been issued for each subdivided lot as time is taken for the survey of the land to be completed. However, in the meantime, buildings which have been erected on the lots have been sold and most of these properties are under mortgage. Under section 8 of the Land Titles Ordinance, there is no provision for the registration of mortgages or other encumbrances created before the issue of the Crown grants. The purpose of the present Bill is to provide the machinery whereby these mortgages or other encumbrances can be protected by notification on the land register kept in the Land Titles Registry.

    The new section 8A. (b) [clause 2] of the Bill puts the responsibility of informing the Registrar of the existence of any mortgage or other encumbrance on the person interested, and paragraph (c) enables the purchaser of the mortgaged property to be registered as proprietor without an order of the Court. This provision is similar to section 13 (6) of the Ordinance.

CROWN LANDS (AMENDMENT) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

2.58 p.m.

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    Section 8 of the Land Titles Ordinance States that after the commencement of the Ordinance any person who has become entitled to land upon alienation by the Crown for an estate in fee simple or for an estate in perpetuity or for a leasehold term of not less than 21 years, can require the Collector of Land Revenue to furnish to the Registrar of Titles a certificate to that effect. The Registrar shall thereupon bring the land under the provisions of the Ordinance as therein directed, and shall deliver the triplicate certificate of title to the person entitled thereto. This complicated provision really means that the Collector of Land Revenue is under a duty to give a certificate to the Registrar of Land Titles who then registers it. But in the case of a statutory land grant issued under section 4 (1) of the Crown Lands Ordinance, the Collector of Land Revenue will be faced with this difficulty. Under section 2 of the Ordinance, a statutory land grant is defined as a grant in perpetuity, but in Schedule A, the Form provides for an estate in fee simple by virtue of the

Column: 1192

words of limitation on "his heirs and assigns for ever". This means, Mr Speaker, Sir, that the Collector will either have to follow the words of the Form, in which case it will be contrary to section 2; or if he goes according to section 2, he will not be going in accordance with the Form and Schedule A. This anomaly has existed since the original Crown Lands Ordinance was passed in 1886. I do not wish now, Mr Speaker, Sir, to labour the House with the intricacies of the difference between a grant and a fee simple and "his heirs and assigns for ever". But I can assure the House that there is a conveyancing difference in the terminology used. For the peace of mind of conveyancers and the Registrar of Land Titles, it is now proposed to remove this anomaly so that the Collector of Land Revenue can certify with certainty that the person to whom Crown land is being alienated is entitled to a grant in perpetuity.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    Bill accordingly read a Second time and committeed to a Committee of the whole Assembly.

    The Prime Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have His Excellency the Yang di-Pertuan Negara's recommendation to proceed with this motion*.


    *The motion reads as follows:

    That this House, in appreciation of their work to preserve peace, and prevent civil war and foreign intervention in the Congo, resolves that a sum of $10,000 be donated to the cheer of troops of the Federation of Malaya serving under United Nations command in the Congo.

DIPHTHERIA IMMUNISATION BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

3.08 p.m.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health (Dr Sheng Nam Chin): Mr Speaker, Sir, -

    Mr Speaker: Will a Minister signify the recommendation of the Yang di-Pertuan Negara?

    The Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Ong Pang Boon): I so signify.

    Dr Sheng Nam Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    Diphtheria is a serious health problem in Singapore and some 600 cases of the disease occur annually with over 50 to 60 deaths. Both the occurence of the disease and deaths are preventable by

Column: 1195

immunisation, and this Bill is designed to improve preventive measures by making immunisation compulsory for infants and children.

    Since 1938 in the City area and after the Second World War in the rural area, it has been the policy to encourage parents to accept inoculation against diphtheria on a voluntary basis. Unfortunately, the response has not been as encouraging as expected. Only approximately 50 per cent of the new-born every year obtained immunisation by the voluntary method. For the effective eradication or reduction of diphtheria, it is necessary that 90 per cent of the children should be immunised. Thus, it is considered to be appropriate at his stage to require compulsory immunisation of all infants and children by primary and booster diphtheria inoculation as defined in clause 2 of the Bill.

    Compulsory immunisation by legislation is neither new nor unorthodox. Children are required to be immunised against diphtheria in such countries as Japan, Canada, Germany, France, the U.S.S.R. and Yugoslavia, and it has been the experience of these countries that such compulsory immunisation sharply decreases the incidence of the disease.

    In the main immunisation will be effected by requiring every child to be administered with primary diphtheria inoculation within 12 months of birth. Alternatively, every child resident in Singapore, who is under the age of seven years and who has not been immunised against diphtheria, will be required to do so under clause 5 of the Bill. Booster diphtheria inoculation, which means a further inoculation against diphtheria for a person who has received a previous inoculation, will be made compulsory for every child residing in Singapore on attaining the age of four years. Provision is also made for a child to obtain a second booster inoculation upon entry to Primary School. Clause 6 refers to booster inoculation.

    Clauses 3 and 4 of the Bill are to ensure that inoculation and intra-dermal test (to test the susceptibility of a person against diphtheria) shall be carried out by qualified persons. Also notification of

Column: 1196

such inoculation and tests must be made to the health authority in a prescribed manner.

    Clause 7 will enable the postponement of diphtheria inoculation if the child is unfit or has acquired immunity or has been shown not liable to diphtheria by means of the intra-dermal test.

    Clause 8 makes it clear that a guardian, which is defined as the person having custody of the child, must present the child for inoculation.

    Diphtheria immunisation will be given free of charge at all Government Maternal and Child Health Centres, but provision is made in clause 9 of the Bill for intra-dermal tests and inoculations to be administered by private medical practitioners at the expense of parents or guardians who choose to obtain inoculation through private doctors.

    To ensure success, some means is required to inform parents of new-born children that they must obtain immunisation under the Bill. Hence, clause 11 provides that the Registrar of Births and Deaths shall issue, after registering a birth, a notice to the guardian directing his attention to his responsibilities. I may say that the Registrar goes through the same procedure in respect of compulsory small-pox vaccination under section 48 of the Quarantine and Prevention of Disease Ordinance.

    Clause 12 provides for penalties for persons who refuse or fail without reasonable excuse to submit to the provisions of the Bill. There are also penalties for obtaining false certificates. You will note, Mr Speaker, Sir, that no prosecution in respect of any offence shall be instituted without the written sanction of the Director of Medical Services.

    According to modern medical practice, it is desirable to cease inoculation in the event of an outbreak of other infectious disease such as poliomyelitis. That is why clause 13 provides for the suspension of any or all the provisions of the Bill as a public health measure.

    Likewise clause 14 provides the Minister with power to declare any area as an area of outbreak of diphtheria, and thereupon to require compulsory inoculation of all children under 12 years of

Column: 1197

age residing therein. In such an emergency, immunisation shall be free of charge.

    Clause 15 provides for the making of regulations generally for carrying out the provisions of the Bill, and includes any fees or charges that it may be necessary to levy for the purpose of carrying out the provisions of the Bill. Among other things, the Minister is also enabled, under clause 15, to regulate the preparation or preparations to be used, the number of occasions they are to be administered, the mode of administration and so on.
